title: Teen killer was 'compared to Gazza' at Newcastle United before going off the rails
text:

A teen killer who fatally stabbed a dad-of-two with a screwdriver was a rising football star who was 'compared to Gazza' at Newcastle United before he went off the rails

Ewan Ireland admits killing Peter Duncan, 52, after the solicitor held a door open for him at a busy shopping centre in Newcastle in August.

Ireland was named and pictured for the first time today after he turned 18.

The fallen football hopeful had been offered a golden opportunity to resurrect his potential career and turn his life around just weeks before he killed Mr Duncan, in Eldon Square.

His footballing potential was spotted at a young age and he played for the Newcastle United Academy as a youngster.

One football coach, who worked with Ireland when he was younger, said: “He was compared to Gazza, he was incredible.

(Image: North News & Pictures Ltd nort)

(Image: North News)

"Everyone in the football community knew of Ewan Ireland because he was outstanding. It’s such a waste.

“He was the best player at the Newcastle United Academy.

"He was unbelievable when he had a football at his feet, but he had a lot of problems off the pitch.

"He had a lot going on in his head. He was naturally gifted, he just didn’t have the right attitude.”

He was released by the academy in 2105, and later excluded by Walbottle Campus school where he had been a pupil.

(Image: North News & Pictures Ltd nort)

(Image: Mirrorpix)

He went on to play at Newbiggin Hall Juniors FC, but was kicked-out after three seasons, when he was 15, for bringing a Stanley knife to training.

Ireland was then given another chance at Newcastle Benfield FC, where he spent just one season.

“He was unstoppable. He was the best footballer in Newcastle at under-9s level,” the coach said. “I can remember watching him and thinking; ‘This is the best kid I have ever seen’.

“He was quite a polite kid, but he was very reclusive.

"He wouldn’t maintain eye contact with you. He didn’t say much. If a big kid had a go he would back off.”

(Image: North News & Pictures Ltd nort)

Ireland lived with his mum in the Westerhope area of Newcastle after it is believed his dad died when he was in his early teens, reports The Chronicle.

Ireland, who played in centre midfield, was offered one last chance at football success just three weeks before he stabbed Mr Duncan on August 14.

It is understood he was offered a place on a BTEC course run by the Newcastle United Foundation, which would have given him the chance to study for a qualification while playing football.

But Ireland rejected the offer.

“I’m aware the Newcastle United Foundation had offered him a place on a BTEC course just three weeks before,” said the coach.

“Any kid would have loved to do that. He hit a crossroads in his life, it’s tragic, he was the best footballer I had ever seen. But you can only try so much.

“On the pitch his knowledge of the game and how it should be played was second-to-none. It’s horrendous what he’s done, but he was always great with me. I have only got fond memories of him.”

At Newcastle Crown Court last month Ireland pleaded guilty to murder having an offensive weapon, namely a screwdriver, and theft of screwdrivers from Poundland.

He will be sentenced in December.
